Britain's Golden Athletes

19/12/2013

Grace Marsh caught up with gold medal-winning athletes Mo Farah and Christine Ohuruogu about SPOTY, what really matters to them and what they have planned for the future

Image by

By undefined undefined

Despite missing out on BBC Sports Personality of the Year awards, British athletes Mo Farah and Christine Ohuruogu should be celebrating this Christmas. Breaking records and retaining titles, both performed outstandingly at this year's World Championships in Moscow. What does next year have in store for them? This year, double Olympic gold medallist Mo Farah's performance at the Moscow World Championships gave him even more a reason to do the 'mobot'. Gold in the 5,000 and 10,000 metres made him only the second person in history to do the 'double-double' at the Olympics and World Championships. It's no wonder then that Farah is thought of by many as one of the best long distance runners of all time, a claim that few would disagree with. For Farah, it is a privilege to be associated with his heroes, "to be looked at in the same way as such great athletes like Coe, Ovett and Cram, it's an honour." Such accolades do not, however, change his love and determination to succeed. Farah's heroes have all won BBC Sports Personality of the Year, an award that Farah was nominated for, but was unsuccessful in this year. Speaking about this year's winner, Andy Murray, Farah describes him as "a great lad" and someone he's watched "with great interest in the past years." Despite the public recognition he receives for his track running, perhaps his constant success on the track is starting to bore him as, next year, Farah is taking on a new challenge: the marathon. After a long year of hard work and triumphs, the long distance runner won't be using Christmas to party. "Party?" He jokes, "I've got a marathon in April!" It is more the opposite; his coach Alberto Salazar has a meticulously planned daily training regime that is "a bit different, a bit harder and a bit more solid," making Mo feel "more tired than ever." Farah has upped his training to running more than 120 miles a week and in his usual nonchalant manner, doesn't seem to be feeling much pressure, as he explains, "it's going alright, going in the right direction." Despite having never run a marathon before, and indeed, having only ever run half that distance competitively, Farah seems excited to throw himself at the prospect. In true competitive style, he aspires to win, declaring "it would be nice to go out there and do your first marathon and do well". However, he understands that the experience might not be so magical the first time round, acknowledging that "it'll probably take three or four times to get it right." Perhaps the new running shoes that Nike are working on for him might make that little big of difference. Farah's coach, Salazar believes that they could effectively take a few minutes off Farah's marathon time. Farah doesn't know if the marathon will suit his running style yet is determined to attempt it regardless, "I could be good at the marathon, I could not be. That's something that I want to try," going on to add: "I had a dream of running through London and having that crowd behind me." Does Farah think the harshly critical British public will remain supportive if his marathon success is unparalleled to his track success? No, in fact, he "loves the British public" and is adamant that "nobody's going to hate you or dislike you because you have a bad race or you have a bad year... it's just what it is." Farah claims that the public were the driving force for his 2012 Olympic success; he loved hearing seventy-five thousand people shouting his name. As well as future victory in a marathon, Farah also has his eyes firmly on Wilson Kipsang. The Kenyan recently set a new marathon world record of 2 hours 3 minutes 23 seconds at the Berlin Marathon this September. Farah and Kipsang seem to be quite well acquainted, as Farah recollects spending "quite a lot of time with him" during training sessions and thought it was nice to see someone he knew break the record. Farah seems more inspired than intimidated by Kipsang's presence but will that inspiration equate to success? Maybe so, but marathon success isn't going to come easy, even for a double-gold World Champion. This year has certainly been one of success for Christine Ohuruogu. After winning silver at the London 2012 Olympics, the 400m British number one has done nothing but impress in 2013. A terrific 400m win over Amantle Montsho by four-thousandths of a second at the Moscow World Championships gave her a second World Title, making her the first British women in history to hold that record. She recently won Sky Sports and Sunday Times Sportswomen of the Year, Cosmopolitan Sportswomen of the Year, and was nominated for BBC Sports Personality of the Year. Ohuruogu's attitude towards her profession is refreshing; it's not medals, but the love of her sport that drives her. "It sounds a bit strange, but we don't just do it to win medals. It's quite nice that I've never really hinged my career on just winning medals. I do have a genuine passion for what I'm doing and I've learnt a lot doing what I'm doing. I'm happy to continue along that road." The twenty-nine-year-old is not planning on retiring anytime soon, and competing in the 2016 Rio Olympics is a definite possibility, providing that she remains injury free and fit enough to compete. "As I stand here now, I think it's really something that I can aim for and I'm perfectly comfortable in saying that". Ohuruogu isn't, however, so confident about the security of her position as world number one. She stresses that anything could happen in the next couple of years, that there is new talent constantly churned out and it's not easy to predict what other people are going to do and how they're going to perform. "People are now watching me, watching how I compete and race, probably changing how they race to accommodate to how I compete." Her response? To continue doing what she does best: "All I can do is what I do when I go to the track everyday, just work hard." She makes it quite clear that she isn't prepared to change her running style. "What I have is what I have. It has proven me well so far. Everybody knows how I run. It's no big secret. I'm no secret, I'm no surprise". Despite the gold in Moscow and setting a new British record, she remains focused and is back in training after a six-week recovery period following the world championships. She won't be taking a break this festive season but she did, however, take some time out to attend BBC Sports Personality of the Year, as she was one of two women nominated. Unfortunately, she didn't come in the top three, but stresses that she is happy to have made the top ten. Her main focus now is on what 2014 will bring: the World Indoors, Commonwealth Games and European Championships. Does Ohuruogu find it difficult to keep herself motivated and continue with her strenuous training regime? "No", she explains, "it's not hard at all. I'm back in training. I enjoy training. It's my job, it's what I do, so it's not going to be difficult at all. I have a good training group and I've got a good coach". 2013's success has brought Ohuruogu increased recognition from the British public, however it's those closer to home, her family and coach Lloyd Cowan, that she cares about most. She explains "to be honest, whether people appreciate it or not, it doesn't really concern me. Me and my coach know what all this hard work means to us. We've been working solidly for the last 10 years and we've been successful for the last 10 years despite our ups and downs. I'm proud of him and he's proud of me and my family are proud of me and that's really what means a lot." Britain's number one is particularly proud of a particular family member, her younger sister Vicky, an up and coming 400m runner, and will "always be her biggest fan." Although, as with every family, there is some competition between the sisters, but Ohuruogu wouldn't call it rivalry because, she explains, "I'm so much older and in any case I want her to eventually aim to beat me." Regardless, it can't be easy growing up in the shadows of one of the world's best 400m runners. Ohuruogu jokes that when she told her sister Vicky that she would be staying on until Rio, she "heard a slight groan because she (Vicky) knows she's going to have to deal with me." 2014 will be a difficult year for Christine Ohuruogu. After this year's achievements, the sporting world will be watching to see if she can continue her impressive run of success. One thing is for sure; she's trying her best.
